biogHist.abstract: A royal commission is a major public inquiry. Usually, royal commissions are inquisitorial in nature, meaning that they are designed to find the 'truth' about a particular incident or allegation. In Australia at the Commonwealth (national) level, royal commissions are established under the terms of the Royal Commissions Act 1902, and this legislation confers the royal commissioner with specific powers to investigate. The powers and scope of a royal commission are also set by the commission's particular terms of reference.
biogHist.p: The Prime Minister of Australia announced the establishment of the Royal Commission into Child Sexual Abuse in November 2012. In the past, there have been a number of other inquiries into this issue, and specifically into the issue of abuse suffered by children in institutional 'care'. These include: the Commission of inquiry into abuse of children in Queensland institutions (1998-1999), Listen to the children: review of claims of abuse from adults in state care as children (Tasmanian Ombudsman, 2003 - 2004), the Senate's Inquiry into children in institutional care (2003-2004), the Children in State Care Committee of Inquiry (South Australia, 2004-2008), the Victorian parliamentary inquiry into Inquiry into handling of child abuse by religious and other organisations (2012 - ), and the Special Inquiry into St Andrew's Hostel [Katanning] (Western Australia, 2011-2012).
